explanation:
To determine whether MHD_add_response_header (or any functions it calls) contains or participates in a for-loop that violates the MISRA requirement, the analyzer must inspect the implementations and relevant type/macros used by the function and its callees. Brief reasons per symbol:

- MHD_str_equal_caseless_: Called repeatedly from the target; its body must be checked for any for-loops and for side effects that would affect loop-clauses of callers.
- charsequalcaseless: Callee of MHD_str_equal_caseless_; include to inspect any loops/side-effects inside the string-comparison implementation.
- add_response_header_connection: Called directly; its body may contain for-loops or modify objects visible to loops in callers, so its source is required.
- add_response_entry: Final fall-through and explicit calls in the function; must be inspected for for-loops and for modifications of objects used in loop headers.
- add_response_entry_n: Callee of add_response_entry; include because loops or side-effects may be deeper in the call chain.
- MHD_get_response_element_n_: Used to obtain header elements; its implementation must be checked for loops and for any modifications to response/header objects.
- _MHD_remove_header: Called to remove a header element; inspect for loops and for modifications of objects that could be used in loop conditions in surrounding code.
- mhd_assert: May be a macro/function; macros can expand to code that contains loops or side effects—include to be safe.
- free: Standard library function called here; include to confirm it has no observable user-level loops/side-effects that would affect MISRA for-loop correctness in this context.
- struct MHD_Response: Definition required to know types of flags_auto/flags and whether they alias or are modified by called functions (important for checking the rule about objects used in loop second/third clauses).
- struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header: Definition required because instances are manipulated/freed; needed to see whether called routines operate on shared objects that could appear in loop clauses.
- MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_: Macro used when calling MHD_get_response_element_n_; macro expansion could affect expressions examined for loop-formation rules.
- MHD_HTTP_HEADER_* (CONNECTION, TRANSFER_ENCODING, DATE, CONTENT_LENGTH): Header-name macros/strings—include to ensure they are simple constants/macro expansions (and not macros that hide loops or side-effects).
- MHD_RAF_HAS_TRANS_ENC_CHUNKED, MHD_RAF_HAS_CONTENT_LENGTH, MHD_RAF_HAS_DATE_HDR, MHD_RF_INSANITY_HEADER_CONTENT_LENGTH, MHD_RF_HEAD_ONLY_RESPONSE: Flag macros used in conditionals and bit-ops; include to confirm they are plain constants (not macros with side-effects) and to understand which response members are read/modified.
- MHD_HEADER_KIND: Value passed to add_response_entry/get element functions; include to see whether it expands to expressions with side-effects.
- enum MHD_Result (MHD_NO, MHD_YES): Return values used by this function and its callees; include to interpret call outcomes which may affect control-flow and potential loop execution.

In short: include the source/definitions of all directly called functions (and their callees listed above), plus the struct/type and macro definitions referenced by the target function, so you can inspect any for-loops and determine whether the three clauses use or modify objects inconsistent with the MISRA rule (including effects of called functions inside loop bodies).
